As well as her equipment, Powder carries a tiny, decorated, clockwork beetle that spits sparks (250 gp), a set of {@item tinker's tools|phb} (50 gp), a {@item spyglass|phb} (1,000 gp), a key to the hidden store in {@area t16|t16}, and 65 gp in assorted coinage.

entries.name: T7. Storm Maiden's Quarters

entries: Two burly humans guard the entrance to these quarters. A woman with wild, white hair marches toward the guards from the central hub of the lair. As she approaches, the three get into a heated conversation which eventually turns to laughter. A moment later, an explosion from the poop deck above draws their attention.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: The two guards are Illuskan {@creature berserker|MM|berserkers} from Norland, loyal to {@creature the Storm Maiden|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}), who appears on deck. The three discuss a prisoner in {@area t18|t18}. Characters who succeed on a DC 12 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check overhear the conversation, which reveals the identity of the prisoner; Lady Doreena Sternquarter—a member of the Lord's Alliance. Tentrix intends to ransom her back to the Alliance for a hefty sum but has refused to send the Storm Maiden to make the trade, which has frustrated her.
After the explosion, the berserkers go to the poop deck to investigate.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: As well as her equipment, the Storm Maiden wears a golden thundercloud pendant with three lightning bolts beneath (25 gp), a gold torc (250 gp), and an ivory bracer (25 gp).
If the characters enter the Storm Maiden's quarters proper, read or paraphrase the following:

This cabin is sparsely furnished, with almost no decoration. The only features are a crossed pair of greataxes behind a hefty wooden shield, painted with red and blue stripes, and a desk against the far wall. A wooden bed, its frame carved in a similar fashion to northlander dragonships, stands nearby.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 15 or higher hear something move beneath the bed. Attempting to hide beneath is a {@creature berbalang|MTF} named Oloc. Oloc is a spectral duplicate of its true form, which hides on the Astral Plane.

Oloc has been hired by the githyanki of Flame Fault on {@area Tuern|tuern|x} to investigate the lair. Oloc wasn't told why to investigate, only to listen for mentions of Purple Rocks and the Astral Plane. So far Oloc has discovered that Tentrix is from Purple Rocks, and is connected to a dark power there.
Oloc can cast {@spell speak with dead}, which may become useful if the characters want to extract information from a dead Tentrix, as the Sea King loses his connection with Slarkrethel when killed.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: There are two {@item greataxe|phb|greataxes} and a {@item shield|phb} mounted on the wall. The desk has three copper flagons emblazoned with dragons atop it (1 gp each) as well as a bottle of fine mead (25 gp).

A large, catapult-type mechanism takes up most this small deck. Clambering around it are three goblins, two of whom attempt to grab something off the third. After a few minutes of evading the others, the goblin gives up and throws a packet toward its pursuers. As one of the goblins catches the packet, it explodes in a ball of flame and smoke, throwing three charred goblin corpses overboard. Shouts of exclamation rise from the deck below.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Characters might intervene before the three {@creature goblin|MM|goblins} blow themselves up with the packet of {@item smokepowder|WDH} ({@adventure appendix C|CallfromtheDeep|13}). The explosion kills the goblins and draws the two {@creature berserker|MM|berserkers} from {@area t7|t7} to investigate. They return to {@area t7|t7} the following round.

entries.name: Weapons
entries: Despite the explosion, the {@object mangonel} (see chapter 8 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}) is still functional. It is not manned unless the characters were spotted (see the {@area Lair Roster Table|lairtable|x}).

entries.name: T9. Desecratus Profanis's Quarters
entries: The door to area t9 is locked with an {@spell arcane lock}—only {@creature Desecratus Profanis|CallfromtheDeep|Desecratus} can open it normally. The door can be opened with a {@spell knock} spell, a successful DC 30 Strength check, or a successful DC 30 Dexterity check using {@item thieves' tools|phb}.

The door is also protected by a {@spell glyph of warding}, discoverable with a successful DC 14 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check. Any creature other than Desecratus that opens the door triggers the glyph, which has the spell {@spell infernal calling|XGE} stored within it. When triggered, the spell summons Ix'thex the Indomitable, a {@creature white abishai|MTF}.
The devil bargains with the characters unless attacked. If the characters can retrieve Ix'thex's devil talisman from Desecratus and bring it to her, she gives them access to Desecratus's quarters.
If the characters gain entry to the chamber, read or paraphrase the following:

Ahead is a chamber dimly lit by purple light. Rows of humanoid skulls lead up to a dark stone dais, engraved with arcane runes, against the back wall. Serpentine forms are engraved into the walls of the cabin, their gaping, fanged maws pointing toward the raised platform.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 14 or higher hear a hissing beneath the dais, and spot holes along its base. Creatures other than Desecratus who step onto the dais are attacked by a {@creature swarm of poisonous snakes} which emerges from the tiny holes.

entries.name: Light
entries: This room is dimly lit.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Characters who succeed on a DC 18 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check notice a ridge at the back of the dais. The ridge is a secret compartment which can be opened with a successful DC 18 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check. Inside is a {@item spellbook|phb} (containing {@spell arcane lock}, {@spell contact other plane}, {@spell glyph of warding}, and {@spell infernal calling|XGE}), a {@item black candle|CallfromtheDeep} with an illusory flame that extinguishes all nonmagical light sources in a room when snuffed, and an obsidian talisman engraved with a cobra head with ruby eyes (2,500 gp).
A brutish minotaur with a leather patch over one eye leans on a ballista, staring into the bay and grunting a sea shanty.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: The {@creature minotaur} on this deck has a missing eye, giving them disadvantage on ranged attack rolls.

entries.name: Weapons
entries: The deck is outfitted with one {@object ballista} (see chapter 8 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}).

entries.name: T11. The Jolly Roger
entries: Descending the stairs from {@area t1|t1} or ascending them from {@area t12|t12} brings the characters to this mezzanine level.
Raucous laughter and the tumbling metre of poorly played instruments fills this balcony. The place is lit by chandeliers of dripping candles that cast light into the hold below.

At one end of the balcony is a recessed bar, where half a dozen humanoids slosh their grog around in tin mugs. Opposite this is a ragged three-piece band atop a table, who are thrashing out a lusty shanty. Before long, a minotaur beating out the staggering rhythm on a battered drum slips in spilt drink and barrels into a seated goblin, throwing them into the air and over the balustrade. The creature lands with a sickening crunch, and the room erupts in laughter.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Hrug (NE male orc {@creature veteran}) mans the bar for three {@creature lizardfolk} and three {@creature orc|MM|orcs}. At the other end of the mezzanine four {@creature bandit|MM|bandits} and two {creature goblin|MM|goblins} clap along to a shanty being played by a {@creature minotaur}, a {@creature bandit} and a plump dwarven {@creature bard|VGM} playing an {@item instrument of the bards, doss lute|dmg|instrument of the bards: doss lute}.

entries.name: Combat
entries: Creatures in area t11 notice intruders in this area if anything falls to area t11, or if there is a loud or highly visible spell effect. The events described in area t11 occur when intruders are discovered.

Fighting in this area gives the pirates a chance to use dirty tactics, battering people with chairs, shoving creatures over the balustrade, igniting bottles of rum to throw, and swinging across the balcony via chandeliers. If characters engage in similar activities, award them with {@variantrule Inspiration}.

entries.name: Service
entries: If the characters are posing as pirates, they can grab an ale and a piece of bread for free at the bar.
The barkeep, a scarred orc named Hrug, chats to them about occurrences in the lair. He reveals that the pirate lords are meeting tomorrow to discuss an attack on Luskan.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The bar is well-stocked with half a dozen bottles of strong spirits (10 gp each). The four chandeliers hanging from the ceiling are gold-plated (100 gp each).

entries.name: T12. Hold
entries: Descending the stairs from {@area t11|t11} brings the characters to this lower level. Read or paraphrase the following:

Sunk into the centre of the lair's hold is an enormous, waterfilled tank, above which the spiral stair curves. Standing around the hold are several individuals; a man in captain's attire whose face is covered in tentacles, a lumbering toadlike humanoid, and a giant purple snake with the face of a woman. Accompanying them are a rag-tag group of pirates.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: When characters enter for the first time {@creature Sea King Tentrix|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}), {@creature Captain Scummer|CallfromtheDeep} ({@creature green slaad}), {@creature Desecratus Profanis|CallfromtheDeep} ({@creature spirit naga}), and four {@creature bandit|MM|bandits} are arguing about the Armada's next move. They cannot decide whether to attack Luskan's navy directly or send mercenaries. Tentrix favours the latter, Profanis the former.
The tank in the room contains an {@creature ogre zombie}.

entries.name: Combat
entries: If a fight breaks out in this room, it alerts the sleeping creatures in {@area t17|t17}, all of whom enter on initiative 10 the following round.

entries.name: Events
entries: If the characters are noticed the following occurs:

items: {@creature Desecratus Profanis|CallfromtheDeep|Desecratus} casts {@spell dominate person} on the first humanoid character she sees, using them to block the spiral stair. She then uses spells that don't require concentration, such as {@spell lightning bolt}, to attack the other characters. The {@creature bandit|mm|bandits} attack with their crossbows.

{@creature Sea King Tentrix|CallfromtheDeep|Tentrix} screams insults at the characters as a {@creature colossal octopus|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) emerges from the hole behind him. He and {@creature Captain Scummer|CallfromtheDeep|Scummer} run over the beast to {@area t13|t13} where Tentrix casts {@spell flesh to stone} from a {@item spell scroll (6th level)|dmg|spell scroll}, turning the colossal octopus into stone, blocking the entrance to {@area t13|t13} after them.

entries.name: Hole
entries: There is a large hole in the deck of the hold that spans into {@area t13|t13}. Lurking beneath is a {@creature colossal octopus|CallfromtheDeep} (see above). Characters can use this hole to enter or exit the lair, via the ocean, from below.

entries.name: Tank & Doors
entries: There is a 25-foot wide, 25-foot deep, 12-foot tall tank set 5-feet lower than the floor level in the centre of the hold. Inside the tank is an {@creature ogre zombie} whose eyes have been plucked from its skull, and whose body festers with multiple wounds. The ship uses the zombie as waste disposal, but also as part of a locking mechanism.

Characters who look into the tank notice pressure plates in each corner. Each of these pressure plates corresponds to the door they are directly opposite (the northwest corner to {@area t19|t19}, for example). Applying a weight of 300 lbs or more to these pressure plates compresses them, causing the matched door to unlock. Removing the weight causes the door to lock again.

The easiest way to trigger the pressure plates is to lure the ogre zombie onto them by holding 'food'; anything from {@item rations (1 day)|phb|rations} to dead goblins, in the water above the plate, or by banging on the glass. The ogre remains where it has been lured until it is lured to another area of the tank.

entries.name: T13. Audience Chamber
entries: To enter this area, characters may have to clear the {@condition petrified} {@creature colossal octopus|CallfromtheDeep|octopus} blocking the entrance. This can be achieved by using a {@item spell scroll (6th level)|dmg|spell scroll} of {@spell flesh to stone} (see {@area t15|t15}) or by casting {@spell dispel magic} (DC 16) upon it. Doing so causes the {@creature colossal octopus|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) to attack the characters, and allows {@creature Sea King Tentrix|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) and {@creature Captain Scummer|CallfromtheDeep} ({@creature green slaad}) to join the fight.

Tentrix is in command of Scummer thanks to owning its control gem. He uses Scummer to take hits, while looking for an opening to escape into the main body of the lair. Tentrix doesn't flee the lair completely, but searches for more allies he can bring into the fight.
If characters enter area t13, read or paraphrase the following:

There is little in this chamber save a throne of melted cutlasses and two tapestries with strange, otherworldly motifs stretching across them. They seem at once to depict swirling masses of dark tentacles, whirlpools of raging waves, spiralling galaxies of stars, and dark, bulbous eyes.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Although unnerving to behold, the tapestries are finely made (250 gp each). Scummer has the key to {@area t3|t3} and his lockbox in his pocket. Tentrix has the key to {@area t14|t14}, the secret store in {@area t16|t16}, and the cells in {@area t18|t18}.

entries.name: T14. Tentrix's Quarters
entries: The door to area t14 is locked. It can be opened with a successful DC 18 Strength check, a successful DC 20 Dexterity check using {@item thieves' tools|phb}, or with a key kept in Tentrix's pocket. When characters enter, read or paraphrase the following:

Beyond the door is a small, cramped bedroom. A low, single bed takes up most of the triangular chamber. The only other furniture is a small wooden desk and chair. The panelling has been engraved with depictions of deep sea creatures, including a kraken which takes up most of the wall.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Atop the desk are numerous papers, most of which are contracts of employment, recruiting captains into the Black Armada. Also in the pile are the identification papers of Lady Doreena Sternquarter ({@area t18|t18}), a report of Black Armada attacks on the Sword Coast, and a note written in {@language Tentrix's Cipher|CallfromtheDeep|Tentrix's cipher} ({@adventure appendix E|CallfromtheDeep|15|Tentrix's Lair Note}).

Characters who look under the bed discover a gold-plated chest (2,500 gp). The chest is locked, Tentrix has the key. It can be opened with a successful DC 20 Strength check, or a successful DC 18 Dexterity check using {@item thieves' tools|phb}.

The chest is trapped with a {@trap poison needle} (see {@book chapter 5|dmg|5|Traps} of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}). Inside is 800 gp in assorted coinage, two emeralds (500 gp each), and a whalebone idol of Slarkrethel (250 gp). A creature that touches the idol has horrifying visions of an enormous brain sinking its tentacles into flesh. The creature must succeed on a DC 20 Wisdom saving throw or take 22 ({@dice 4d10}) psychic damage and suffer a {@table long-term madness} effect (see {@variantrule madness|dmg|chapter 8} of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}).

entries.name: T15. Treasure Chamber
entries: The door to this chamber is barred by a mechanism connected to a pressure plate in {@area t12|t12}. Characters can open the door without compressing the plate with a successful DC 25 Strength check. Written on the lintel is the word 'treasure' in Tentrix's cipher: treasure.
Lorsque les personnages entrent, lisez ou paraphrasez ce qui suit :
This room contains three large, wooden chests inlaid with whalebone, mother of pearl, and coral.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The chests are unlocked. Each is worth 500 gp. Inside the first are dozens of empty vials and containers, six {@item potion of healing|DMG|potions of healing}, two {@item potion of greater healing|DMG|potions of greater healing}, two {@footnote {@i potions of swimming}|This item doesn't exist, but the {@item potion of water breathing} is the closest match. You can use this invented {@item potion of swimming|CallfromtheDeep} otherwise.}, one {@item potion of frost giant strength}, one {@item potion of diminution}, and one {@item potion of longevity}.

Inside the second are eighty-one azurites (10 gp each), sixty-four malachites (10 gp each) seventy-three turquoises (10 gp each), six moonstones (50 gp each), and an {@item elemental gem, emerald|dmg|elemental gem: emerald}.

Inside the third are the possessions of {@creature Lady Doreena Sternquarter|CallfromtheDeep}: a {@item folding boat}, {@item leather armor|phb|leather armour} emblazoned with the symbol of the Lord's Alliance (15 gp), a {@item rapier|phb} with a star of sapphires in the pommel (150 gp), an {@item explorer's pack|phb} (10 gp), and five {@item dagger|phb|daggers} (10 gp); plus the worthless equipment of {@creature Azzakh Norixius|CallfromtheDeep} and his crew (see {@area t18|t18} for descriptions of Doreena and Azzakh).

entries.name: T16. Storeroom
entries: The door to this chamber is barred by a mechanism connected to a pressure plate in {@area t12|t12}. Characters can open the door without compressing the plate with a successful DC 25 Strength check. Written on the lintel is the word 'store' in Tentrix's cipher: store.
Lorsque les personnages entrent, lisez ou paraphrasez ce qui suit :
Crates and barrels piled up to the ceiling fill this chamber. Tools hang from a wall-mounted rack beside the door.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: This room contains eight-hundred rations (5 sp each), one-hundred kegs of ale (5 gp each), one-hundred {@item oil (flask)|phb|flasks of oil} (1 sp each), and a set of {@item tinker's tools|phb} (50 gp).

entries.name: Secret Door
entries: Characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 15 or higher notice an inconsistency with the panelling of this room. Characters who succeed on a successful DC 15 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check discover small, hidden hinges, a keyhole, and a note which says 'BEWARE SMOKEPOWDER' in {@language Tentrix's cipher|CallfromtheDeep}:
BEWARE SMOKEPOWDER
The door has two keys; one owned by Powder, the other by Tentrix. The door can be opened with a successful DC 10 Strength check, or a DC 20 Dexterity check using {@item thieves' tools|phb}.

The room contains five kegs of {@item smokepowder|WDH} ({@adventure appendix C|CallfromtheDeep|13}). A character that opens the door with a Strength check barges through the secret door and runs the risk of colliding with the kegs. The creature must succeed on a DC 20 Dexterity check or hit the barrels, causing them to explode.
Strung up in this room are two dozen hammocks, one row atop the other. A handful of figures lie in the gently swinging beds, snoozing off their last round of grog. The chamber reeks of sweat and ale.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Three {@creature goblin|MM|goblins}, two {@creature orc|MM|orcs}, and a {@creature bandit} are sleeping in this room (unless they left for {@area t12|t12} after hearing a fight). One of the goblins has smuggled a pet {@creature monkey|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) aboard, who wears a small tricorn hat and throws groundnut shells at pretty much anyone.

entries.name: T18. Prison
entries: The door to this chamber is barred by a mechanism connected to a pressure plate in {@area t12|t12}. Characters can open the door without compressing the plate with a successful DC 25 Strength check. Written on the lintel is the word 'prison' in {@language Tentrix's cipher|CallfromtheDeep}: prison
Lorsque les personnages entrent, lisez ou paraphrasez ce qui suit :

Rows of rust-covered iron bars separate this room into two distinct prison cells. Slumped in the corner of one of the cells is an unconscious woman with greasy grey hair and a black eye. A thick padlock hangs from the door of her cell. The second cell contains a gold dragonborn and a two humans.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: The cell contains the {@condition unconscious} {@creature Lady Doreena Sternquarter|CallfromtheDeep} (LG female Chondathan human {@creature swashbuckler|VGM}). Lady Doreena was fighting pirates along the Sword Coast when she was kidnapped by the Black Armada. Realising her potential worth, they brought her back to Tentrix's lair. Tentrix intends to ransom her back to the Lord's Alliance.

Lady Sternquarter returns to consciousness in {@dice 1d10} minutes. When she awakens, she begs the characters to find her equipment before they help her escape, so she can assist them. She has a {@item folding boat}, which they can use to escape if need be. {@dice 1d4 + 1} rounds after she wakes, Filch, Tentrix's {@creature homunculus}, appears to poison her again.

The second cell contains {@creature Azzakh Norixius|CallfromtheDeep} (NG male gold dragonborn {@creature bandit captain}) and two human {@creature guard|MM|guards}; the remnants of the crew of the Bobbing Barrel (see "{@area Orlumbor|orlumbor|x}" and "{@area Asavir's Channel|asavirs channel|x}"). Their ship was sunk by the Curse of Irphong, and most of the crew killed. They were spared to be ransomed back to Llhamaruntosz.
Each prisoners' equipment is in {@area t15|t15}.

entries.name: Cells
entries: The cells are made of iron bars sunk into the deck and ceiling. The bars can be battered down with a successful DC 25 Strength check. The padlock locking the cells can be picked with a successful DC 20 Dexterity check using {@item thieves' tools|phb}. Tentrix has both keys.

entries.name: T19. Trapped Chamber
entries: The door to this chamber is barred by a mechanism connected to a pressure plate in {@area t12|t12}. Characters can open the door without compressing the plate with a successful DC 25 Strength check. Written on the lintel in {@language Common} is the word 'gold'. Beneath this is the word 'cursed' written in Tentrix's cipher: cursed.
Lorsque les personnages entrent, lisez ou paraphrasez ce qui suit :

An enormous pile of gold coins fills this chamber. The wooden panelling is engraved with depictions of pirates digging up chests, a pirate king atop a throne surrounded by treasure, and a skeleton buried under thousands of coins.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The room contains a pile of 180,000 {@item cursed gold coin|CallfromtheDeep|gp}, each minted with a skull on its 'head' and crossbones on its 'tail'. The gold coins are worth the same amount as a normal gold piece and could be melted down into gold bars or swapped for 'normal' gold pieces at a money changer.

entries.name: Curse
entries: The gold pieces are cursed, a fact revealed only when an {@spell identify} spell is cast on the coin, or after the effects of the curse become apparent. Casting {@spell detect magic} reveals an aura of necromancy around the gold. Any creature that carries the gold for an hour or more is cursed. The curse can only be removed by {@spell remove curse} or similar magic, and does not end if the creature disposes of the gold.

While cursed, the creature's type becomes undead. In {@dice 1d4} days, the creature loses all appetite for food and drink and no longer needs them to survive. {@dice 1d4} days after that, the creature loses all need for air or sleep. {@dice 1d4} days after that, the creature's flesh begins to slough off its bones, leaving it a bare skeleton. This process takes {@dice 1d10} days and, while mildly painful and grotesque, has no effect on the creature's hit points. After the transformation is complete, the creature gains the following changes:

items: Their Dexterity score increases by 2.
Their Strength score decreases by 2.
Their Charisma score decreases by 4.
They gain vulnerability to bludgeoning damage and immunity to poison damage.
They can't be {@condition poisoned}, or gain levels of {@condition exhaustion}.
They gain sense {@sense darkvision} out to a range of 60 feet.
They are undead.

entries.name: T20. Crow's Nest
entries: Ascending the stairs from {@area t1|t1} brings the characters to this open-air upper level. Read or paraphrase the following:

Atop the decks of the lashed-together ships is a wooden, octagonal platform surrounded on all sides by a balustrade. From this platform rises a thick mast, draped with a red sail. Each corner of the balustrade has a large crossbow bolted to it, several of which are armed by gruff-looking orcs. Behind the ship's wheel is a gaunt, hooded figure leaning on an oar with a small, winged creature on its shoulder.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Four {@creature orc|MM|orcs} man the {@object scorpio|CallfromtheDeep|scorpios} (see below). Behind the wheel is {@creature Kharon|CallfromtheDeep} (see "{@footnote Lesser Pirates|Moved to the Info tab of Kharon's bestiary entry.}"), who was hired by Tentrix to protect the ship. Kharon uses their lair actions and regional effects in the lair's defence but does not fight, and teleports away if threatened.

Kharon can be bribed to disclose information about the layout of the lair and its inhabitants for 1,000 gp. For 10 gp a day, Kharon can captain the character's ship, protecting it using their lair actions and regional effects.
On Kharon's shoulder is Tentrix's {@creature homunculus}, Filch. He telepathically communicates the location of the characters to Tentrix, and follows them through the lair if it can.

entries.name: Weapons
entries: Each balustrade corner is fitted with a {@object scorpio|CallfromtheDeep} ({@hit 5} to hit, range 120/360 ft., one target; 11 ({@dice 2d10}) piercing damage on a hit; it takes one action to load a scorpio, and one action to fire it). Each scorpio has ten bolts nearby.

entries.name: Lookout
entries: Characters who climb the 50-foot rope-ladder up the mast come to a small lookout spot. In the lookout is Blug, a {@creature goblin} with {@item eyes of the eagle}. Blug would rather become the slave of the characters than die and begs for mercy if threatened.

entries.name: Development
entries: By the time characters have raided the floating lair of Sea King Tentrix and dealt with the pirates within, they may have uncovered some of the following information:

items: Tentrix works for the kraken, Slarkrethel.
Tentrix comes from Purple Rocks.
Tentrix is responsible for creating the Black Armada and attacking the Sword Coast

entries: This information should lead the characters to Purple Rocks, where they can infiltrate the headquarters of the Kraken Society and discover the location of Ascarle, where Slarkrethel the kraken lairs.

entries.name: Character Advancement
entries: After the characters have defeated Sea King Tentrix, they should reach at least 9th level.

entries.name: Purple Rocks
entries: Purple Rocks can be found on almost any map of the Sword Coast and Island Kingdoms and is a relatively easy location to travel to. Although the Rocklanders don't receive many visitors, or trade much with the other Island Kingdoms, they are well-known shipwrights capable of repairing damaged vessels, or sheltering crews when there are storms. The real challenge comes if characters want to leave Utheraal, the 'public island' where visitors are housed.

entries.name: Sea-Kings and Deep Lords
entries: Although nominally ruled over by two kings, Sea-King Frannis of Utheraal and Sea-King Krulk of Trissk (CN male Illuskan human {@creature gladiator|MM|gladiators}), Purple Rocks is actually controlled by a circle of five Deep Lords: {@creature kraken priest|VGM|kraken priests} known to the Rocklanders as the Elders. Though each Deep Lord is equal, {@creature Deep Lord Ingrimarr|CallfromtheDeep} (NE non-binary Illuskan human {@creature warlock of the great old one|VGM} with Hoch Miraz's {@item staff of the magi}) is the voice of the council and acts as the mouthpiece for Slarkrethel the kraken. Each Elder's connection with the kraken means that Slarkrethel, or now Zellix'Phor, can kill them telepathically by using an action to deal psychic damage to them.

All of the Elders know something is wrong with Slarkrethel, though they don't know what. Their efforts to placate the kraken, such as throwing children into the sea, have failed to produce the usual effects: abundant fish stocks and protection from the northerly storms. In an effort to appease Slarkrethel, they have been taking more drastic measures, such as sacrificing humanoids who visit the islands. In addition to the lack of action by Slarkrethel, strange creatures have been visiting the islands, who seem linked to the kraken. These visitors are the mind flayer Attendants of Zellix'Phor, who devour the brains of Rocklanders for sustenance, and take others below the waves for ceremorphosis.

The only weak link in the hierarchy of Purple Rocks is Sea-King Frannis. Frannis cannot believe that Slarkrethel has abandoned them, and does not understand why their efforts have not pleased the kraken. He is also distrustful of the 'visitors' who haunt his crumbling castle. Given the chance, Frannis makes a break to escape the island and begs the characters for protection.

entries.name: Utheraal
entries: When characters arrive at Purple Rocks they are greeted by a {@item longship|CallfromtheDeep} crewed by forty {@creature tribal warrior|mm|tribal warriors}, many of whom boast tattoos of stylised tentacles wrapping around their biceps. Read or paraphrase the following:

Headed toward you is a longship with a kraken prow. The burly men who crew the boat look sullen, but not aggressive. As the ship cuts through the waves and draws closer, a man heads to the prow and beckons. His skin seems loose around his face, showing the pink waterline beneath his bulging eyes.

Once characters are within earshot, the man asks why they're visiting Purple Rocks. If they give a reasonable explanation such as to restock on supplies, shelter from a storm, or get repair their ship, he escorts them to Utheraal.

If characters arrive at Purple Rocks by other means, such as flight or teleportation, you should adjust the text to match their arrival. No matter how they arrive, the characters are escorted to Vilkstead Castle on Utheraal, where they meet with Sea-King Frannis.
While staying in Vilkstead, the characters might notice a few strange traits of the locals:

items: The Rocklanders often converse in a unique version of {@language Deep Speech} which sounds like sloshing ooze.
The Rocklanders have an unpleasant smell to them: a mix of fish and rotting onions.
The skin of the Rocklanders seems loose and rubbery or scarred and weather-beaten. Their eyes are rheumy and their hair lank and greasy.

The population seems to be mostly young to middle-aged men. The characters might spot the occasional woman but never see a young or old person. It is not unusual for Northlanders to house visitors away from the women given their patriarchal, misogynistic culture, but no other Norls hide away their young and elderly.
The Rocklanders sometimes fall into a trance, staring toward the ocean for hours on end.
Some of the Rocklanders have webbed fingers and toes, and folded skin on their necks which resembles gills.

entries.name: Unfathomable Horror
Content Warning
entries: {@i The following is intended to horrify.}

Purple Rocks is inhabited by folk whose lives have been corrupted by veneration of Slarkrethel. Although their day-to-day life seems similar to that of any Norl community, the Rocklanders hide the sinister secret driving their culture.
While staying on Purple Rocks, the characters bear witness to disturbing events. If you want to enhance the horror of the location, use the following rules to assist you:

entries.name: Horror
entries: Horror involves more than simple fright. It entails revulsion and anguish. It arises when adventurers see something completely contrary to their understanding of the world, or upon the realisation of a dreadful truth.

In such a situation, you can call on the characters to make a Charisma saving throw to resist the horror. Disturbing events that occur on the islands have a DC noted next to them, but you can set the DC yourself based on the magnitude of the horrific circumstances. On a failed save, the character gains a {@table short-term madness} effect, or a {@table long-term madness|DMG|long-term} effect if the save fails by 5 or more, that you choose or determine randomly (see {@variantrule madness|dmg|chapter 8} of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}).

entries.name: Sanity Scores
entries: If you want to leave a psychological scar on characters, and have their consent, you can introduce a new score: Sanity. A character's Sanity score equals their Wisdom modifier + Charisma modifier (minimum of 2). It is an indication of how well they can bear the consequences of confronting disturbing circumstances and resist the call of madness.
Characters can spend a Sanity point to help them succeed in certain situations. They can expend a point of Sanity to automatically succeed on:

items: An ability check to understand eldritch clues, such deciphering the mind-warping text on a shrine to Slarkrethel.
A Charisma saving throw to resist horror.

entries: Whenever a character gains a form of madness they lose a Sanity point. A {@spell greater restoration} spell restores a point of Sanity to a creature who still has at least one point remaining. If a character's Sanity is reduced to 0, they go indefinitely insane—their mind is so corrupted by horror that they cannot continue. The character might die of a heart attack, commit suicide, or be reduced to a gibbering mess. Any spell that brings a character back to life, such as {@spell raise dead}, restores the character and their Sanity score, but they return with a form of indefinite madness that cannot be removed short of a {@spell wish} spell. Choose or determine the madness from the table below:

colLabels: Flaw (lasts until cured by a {@spell wish} spell)
rows: "I adorn myself with fish skeletons, wash in sea water, and wear clothes of matted seaweed."
"I have been contacted by Slarkrethel, who speaks to me through my dreams."
"I am convinced I must immerse myself in salt water every eight hours or I will die."
"Defeating Slarkrethel is my only aim. Nothing will stand between me and my goal."
"I only eat raw fish and seaweed."
"I pick at my skin constantly, trying to find the scales and suckers that I know are underneath."
"The ocean terrifies me; being on the coast gives me jitters, being submerged would kill me."
"I am convinced that the Kraken Society are hunting me, and their agents watch me always."
"I see writhing tentacles in the shadows. They are horrors of the deep that want to devour me."
"I can't take anything seriously. The more serious the situation, the funnier I find it."
"Human sacrifice is the only way to appease the kraken, Slarkrethel."

entries.name: Locations in Vilkstead
entries: When characters arrive on the southern island of Utheraal they are escorted to Vilkstead, a fishing settlement of slate-roofed shacks, thatched longhouses, and plain, granite shrines. The island has a purple hue beneath the stormy sky that hangs perpetually over Purple Rocks. The characters are taken to Vilkstead Castle to meet with Sea-King Frannis, then to a longhouse where they can rest during their stay. While characters remain on the island they can explore freely, but are not permitted to leave without an escort (see the "{@area Leaving Utheraal|leaving utheraal|x}" section).

The following sections detail areas of interest, as well as a disturbing encounter that occurs when the characters first arrive there. These encounters can be moved to other locations, or occur at a different time of your choosing.

entries.name: Harbour
entries: The main feature of Vilkstead is its large, open bay that is protected from the northern winds (known to the Norls as Aurilsbreath) by high-cliffs and mountains. Within the bay is a deep harbour that shelters a handful of kraken-headed {@item longship|CallfromtheDeep|longships} and many more small fishing vessels. Small groups of male Rocklanders sit fishing off the edge of rotting piers with long rods and crabbing lines.

entries.name: Disturbing Encounter (DC 14)
entries: One of the fishermen suddenly begins choking and spluttering: a sickening, squelching noise. After a few retches the man coughs up a live eel that flops in a pool of regurgitated slime on the pier. Quickly, one of the other men whacks the eels over the head with a wooden cudgel and slings it into their keep net.

entries.name: Beach
entries: On the stretch of coast east of the bay is a long, black sand beach. Although the beach is picturesque, the unceasing sound of the tide pulling at the shore makes you uneasy. A few fishing boats ply the waters not far from shore.

entries.name: Disturbing Encounter (DC 12)
entries: While characters check out the beach, a fishing boat grounds itself on the sandy shore. The Rocklanders disembark from the boat and dump a pile of empty nets on the ground. Then, three of the men grab the corpse of a dolphin from the boat while the other two start a driftwood fire. With terrifying efficiency, the three gut the dolphin and throw its viscera into the flames producing a sour, acrid smoke. They make quick work of butchering the dolphin and carry the meat to Vilkstead.

entries.name: Development
entries: Characters who succeed on a DC 12 Intelligence ({@skill Nature}) check know that dolphin meat is not good to eat. The Rocklanders must be doing so as a last resort because of low fish stocks.

entries.name: Guest Longhouse
entries: The characters are invited to stay in a mouldering wooden longhouse, the thatched ceiling of which is white and furry with mildew. The longhouse consists of a large communal hall, with four private chambers off a corridor at the far end. During the day, the communal area is frequented by young men eating a rank fish stew and smoking pipes.

entries.name: Disturbing Encounter (DC 10)
entries: At any time two or more Rocklanders are in the communal space, the characters overhear a conversation. They speak in a malign vernacular whose utterance is reminiscent of a drowned man coughing up seawater (a derivate of {@language Deep Speech} known only to the Rocklanders). The sound of the speech is utterly chilling.

entries.name: Development
entries: Characters who can understand {@language Deep Speech} can attempt a DC 18 Intelligence check to understand the conversation. On a success, the character understands a smattering of the discussion; the Elders are meeting later today to discuss a festival of some sort due to take place tonight.

entries.name: Granite Shrines
entries: Spread around Vilkstead are half a dozen plain, granite shrines. At first glance, these standing stones appear to be nothing more than that, but it's clear there's more than meets the eye. Whenever a Rocklanders walks past a stone, they are sure to stop and press their palms against it.

entries.name: Disturbing Encounter (DC 15)
entries: Any character that places their palm upon a standing stone has their mind twisted by the resoundingly evil psyche of the kraken Slarkrethel, controlled at this time by Zellix'Phor.

Terrifying hallucinations of enveloping, oily waves from the Tarterian depths, filled with squamous tentacles belonging to unknown horrors flood the creature's mind. To the Rocklanders, this connection with the kraken keeps them enthralled; to outsiders, it is madness-inducing.

entries.name: Abandoned Temple
entries: A short walk from the centre of Vilkstead, in a shadowed grove of tall pines, is a rotting, antiquarian temple with a many-tiered, gabled roof supported by thick wooden pillars whose grain is stained a deep red hue. The wooden temple does not seem to be frequented by the Rocklanders, though the trail that leads to the temple is clear of vegetation.

Inside, the temple is filled with a charnel stench. The wooden boards are mouldering and seem to ooze a viscous, scarlet sap. With each gust of wind the structure moans like an injured animal. The rooms of the temple are curiously empty, save for the innermost chamber, a balcony-crowned hall, which contains a towering form covered by a fungus-peppered sailcloth.

entries.name: Disturbing Encounter (DC 15)
entries: If the sailcloth is removed, an aged wooden statue is revealed. The statue is of a broad, muscular Northman whose arms have been mutated into writhing tentacles of a singularly unholy quality. Where the wood is cracked with age, a pustulent, pallid fungi has encroached, filling the spaces with globular, sucker-like growths. The malformed man towers to a height of fourteen feet.

Atop the moist plinth on which the statue stands is the pallid, festering corpse of an unrecognisable humanoid. The carcass's flesh is bloated and webbed with blackened veins, and it lies in a turbid puddle of liquid. The corpse is clutching a jade scroll case (200 gp) in its rigor-mortised fist. The parchment inside bears a drawing of an iron gate ({@adventure appendix E|CallfromtheDeep|15|Sketch of Ascarle's Entrance}). Pillars to either side are topped with a strange statue; a loathsome creature of singular character, whose cephalopodic nature is betrayed by the presence of leathery, bat-like wings and a crouched, humanoid frame.
Characters who explore Trisk's northern shore can locate the remnants of the pillars and gate within a few days. This is the location of Ascarle—the lair of Slarkrethel.

entries.name: Development
entries: A successful DC 16 Intelligence ({@skill Religion}) check reveals that the statue was once of {@deity Valkur|Faerûnian|scag}, the Northlander god of courage, strength, and sailing skill.

Characters who succeed on a DC 18 Intelligence ({@skill History}) check ascertain that the alterations to its form have occurred more recently, as the cracks of age are less prevalent in the wood of the tentacles.

Characters who examine the corpse and succeed on a DC 12 Wisdom ({@skill Medicine}) check determine the cause of death as drowning. If the check succeeds by 5 or more, they gather that the creature suffered necrotic damage before death. A successful DC 18 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check reveals the puddle to be a {@creature slithering tracker|VGM}; the cause of death. If characters don't notice the tracker it follows them from the temple, waiting for the right time to strike.

entries.name: Vilkstead Castle
entries: This crumbling edifice leers down over the harbour from the high cliffs to its north. The fort is battered constantly by a frigid north wind that whips around the ruinous structure, creating a mournful wailing that echoes throughout. The auditory assault is only worsened by the unceasing crashing of waves against the rocky coastline below.

entries.name: Disturbing Encounter (DC 15)
entries: When characters first arrive in Vilkstead, they are escorted to the castle by ten {@creature tribal warrior|MM|tribal warriors}. They enter the fort through a dilapidated gateway, guarded by two rheumy-eyed {@creature berserker|MM|berserkers}.

As the characters are led into the habitable region of the ruins they pass through a domed, circular chamber whose walls are engraved with crashing wave motifs. There is a 5-foot radius hole in the centre of the floor which drops several hundred feet to the ocean below. Three {@creature berserker|MM|berserkers} lead a bound {@creature commoner} to the hole and throw him down. A figure cloaked in a head-to-toe black veil—a {@creature mind flayer} created by ceremorphosis—watches over the process.

Characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 20 or higher notice the veil wafts over the stone floor as if the figure is floating. Characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 25 or higher notice the obscured form of tentacles where the figure's mouth should be, and must succeed on a DC 12 Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition frightened} of the figure for 1 minute.

entries.name: Development
entries: Soon after, characters arrive in the presence of Sea-King Frannis (CN male Illuskan human {@creature gladiator}) and four {@creature berserker} bodyguards. Frannis is a gaunt man whose mouth hangs open revealing a row of repulsive brown teeth. Frannis was a devout worshipper of Slarkrethel, but recent events have broken his faith.

Frannis greets the characters, shaking their hands in his own clammy claws. He tells them that they are welcome to stay in the guest longhouse for as long as they need, though they are not permitted to leave the island. As he talks, the {@creature mind flayer} from the previous room enters, causing Frannis to break out in a cold sweat. Characters who succeed on a DC 10 Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) check can see desperation or madness in his bug-eyed stare. Frannis permits the characters to leave for to the longhouse.
If characters ask about the execution, Frannis proclaims; 'Those who displease the Deep Gods must take the Traitor's Plunge', in a stentorian voice that is not his own.

entries.name: Events in Vilkstead
entries: During their stay in Vilkstead, the characters might witness the following events. The encounter with Sea-King Frannis should propel the story forward if characters seem lost.

entries.name: Desperate Flight
entries: One night, Sea-King Frannis flees his castle in desperation. His nerves have worn thin thanks to the presence of mind flayers in his home and the strange occurrences on Purple Rocks. The characters wake up to the sound of Frannis entering their longhouse. He makes a plea for them to leave the islands and take him with them, claiming there are strange beings in his castle, Slarkrethel is dead, and his court has turned against him. Frannis tells the characters as much of the following information as you deem necessary to progress the story:

items: The Rocklanders venerate a kraken named Slarkrethel, but he has been killed by alien forces.
The kraken lairs north of Trisk in the underwater ruins of the city of Ascarle.
One of the creatures that killed Slarkrethel transformed Frannis's brother into one of their kind, a loathsome, tentacle-faced monster.

entries.name: Development
entries: Not long after {@creature gladiator|mm|Frannis} arrives, the characters are disturbed again as a gang of Rocklanders bursts into the longhouse looking for him. The group consists of three mind flayer thrall {@creature berserker|MM|berserkers} and two {@creature deep scion|VGM|deep scions}, led by the {@creature mind flayer} from Vilkstead Castle.

The Rocklanders try to seize Frannis. When he resists, the deep scions undergo a hideous transformation; the skin around their mouths peels away to reveal rows of needlelike teeth, and their limbs sprout fish-like fins. Any character that sees the transformation must succeed on a DC 15 Wisdom saving throw or gain a random form of short-term madness, determined by rolling on the {@table Short-Term Madness} table in {@variantrule madness|dmg|chapter 8} of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}.

Unless characters intervene, the group takes Frannis to the beach and out into the shallows. The Rocklanders surround the Sea-King before the mind flayer, or another Rocklander, uses a knife to slit his throat and holds his head beneath the breaking waves.
Characters who save Frannis receive answers to any questions about Slarkrethel, the Rocklanders, and the mind flayer inhabitants of Purple Rocks.

entries.name: Children of the Deep
entries: One night, when the full moon is high above the islands, the characters are awoken by the sound of children crying. Out on the harbour cliffs, a gathering of a dozen Rocklander {@creature commoner|MM|commoners} overseen by three {@creature deep scion|VGM|deep scions} hold their newborn babies over the edge, above the crashing waves below. As characters watch, the babies are flung into the roiling ocean. A dozen {@creature sea spawn|CallfromtheDeep} climb up the cliffs and engage in a blasphemous ritual with the Rocklanders; a hedonistic, swirling dancing lit by flickering green flames, followed by a feast on the corpse of a shark. After the ritual is complete, the sea spawn jump from the cliffs into the ocean depths once more, and the Rocklanders return to their homes.

If characters intervene in any way with the ceremony they are attacked by all present. The Rocklanders try to {@action shove} the characters of the cliffs. If they succeed, the characters are captured by another twelve {@creature sea spawn|CallfromtheDeep} who take them to Ascarle. Any characters that witness the deep scions transform must succeed on a DC 15 Wisdom saving throw or gain a random form of short-term madness, determined by rolling on the {@table Short-Term Madness} table in {@variantrule madness|dmg|chapter 8} of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}.

entries.name: Leaving Utheraal
entries: At some point the characters may want to leave Utheraal, against the requests of the Rocklanders.

entries.name: By Sea
entries: If characters leave by boat, they are met by a {@item longship|CallfromtheDeep} crewed by forty {@creature tribal warrior|MM|tribal warriors}, led by a {@creature deep scion|VGM}. The squid-headed ship herds characters out into the Trackless Sea, blocking their path to Trisk. If characters try to head in that direction, the longship cuts them off.

Characters leaving at night can attempt a DC 16 group Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) check to avoid being seen. This is impossible during the day unless characters create a large distraction, such as setting a building aflame.

entries.name: By Land
entries: Characters leaving by land have the chance of slinking away unnoticed by succeeding on a DC 14 group Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) check. The check is made with advantage at night. If the check fails, the characters are hounded by a gang of six {@creature berserker|MM|berserkers} who try to turn them back, using violence if necessary. The characters must wait at least 12 hours before attempting to leave again. If characters are caught twice, they are asked to leave Purple Rocks and are escorted by a {@item longship|CallfromtheDeep} (see above).

After escaping, characters must endure two days of random encounters while travelling across the islands. During this time, six {@creature berserker|MM|berserkers} mounted on {@creature riding horse|MM|riding horses} catch up with the characters and try to return them to Vilkstead. Once characters reach the northwest shore, they can swim for ten miles to the island of Trisk if they have a swim speed, or must use a boat or raft to make the journey, arriving just east of Ulf of Thuger.

entries.name: Flying & Teleportation
entries: There is little the Rocklanders can do to prevent the characters using magic to escape Vilkstead. However, the use of such magic alerts the {@creature mind flayer} in Vilkstead Castle of the characters movements. The illithid can then pursue the characters wherever they go, or alert the Elders on Trisk of their disappearance.

entries.name: Trisk
entries: Unlike Utheraal, the island of Trisk does not welcome visitors. The Rocklanders of Trisk are the most devout and include among their number a circle of kraken priests known as the Elders, and a small group of {@creature sea spawn|CallfromtheDeep} and deep scions who do not lair with Slarkrethel in Ascarle. Characters who find themselves on Trisk are sure to witness the true horror of Slarkrethel worship.

Trisk is uninhabited save for Ulf of Thuger, and a nameless encampment on the northernmost point of the island where the kraken priests commune directly with Slarkrethel when the stars align. The land and sea around Ulf of Thuger are patrolled night and day by gangs of six {@creature deep scion|VGM|deep scions} led by a {@creature kraken priest|VGM}, who attempt to capture any intruders and take them to the Temple of Tentacles.

Each day the characters spend in Ulf of Thuger, the characters can attempt a DC 16 Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) check to move around cautiously, with success indicating that they avoid drawing attention to themselves.
While spending time in Ulf of Thuger, characters might notice the following:

items: Many of the Rocklanders are horrifyingly deformed; their skin is covered in chitinous plates, they have multiple rows of teeth that occasionally fall out, or their fingertips are mutated into octopus-like suckers.
Like the Rocklanders of Vilkstead, those from Ulf of Thuger reek of rotting fish and sulphur, and converse in a hideous, choking dialect.

There are 'other' creatures among the Rocklanders that the characters never quite see in full. These dreadful, Chthonic, beings vary from grotesque, hump-backed monstrosities to loathsome, amorphous aberrations. If the characters try to search out these beings, their minds fail to comprehend their ghastly forms, corrupting their very souls with insidious madness.

entries.name: Temple of Tentacles
entries: The only building of note within Ulf of Thuger is the Temple of Tentacles, a domed, granite building which resembles a squid standing erect on spiralling tentacles. The temple is on the shoreline, allowing the ocean to wash inside at high tide to a depth of 1 foot.

{@creature elder kraken priest|CallfromtheDeep|The Elders}, a group of five {@creature kraken priest|VGM|kraken priests} led by {@creature Deep Lord Ingrimarr|CallfromtheDeep} (NE non-binary Illuskan human {@creature warlock of the great old one|VGM} with a {@item staff of the magi}), meet each dusk and dawn here to discuss Slarkrethel, Purple Rocks, and their veneration. They have limited knowledge about the Kraken Society but know of its existence. They occasionally meet with Krakenar agents to enact Slarkrethel's plans.

entries.name: Unholy Engravings
entries: Inside, the temple is covered with fractured, sacrilegious hieroglyphics. Characters who see the engravings must succeed on a DC 12 Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition frightened} of them. If the saving throw fails by 5 or more, the character also gains a form of short-term madness, determined by rolling on the {@table Short-Term Madness} table in {@variantrule madness|dmg|chapter 8} of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}.

entries.name: Secret Door
entries: Characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 18 or higher notice a secret door at the rear of the temple. A character can open the door with a successful DC 18 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check. The priests escape through this door if they are attacked.

entries.name: Statue
entries: In the centre of the chamber is a kraken statue. Deep Lord Ingrimarr watches and disciplines prisoners using an {@spell arcane eye} and {@spell magic mouth} cast on the statue.

entries.name: Capture
entries: If the characters are captured on Purple Rocks, they are bound in handcuffs and manacles, stripped of their belongings, and chained to rings in the temple alcoves.

Characters can hide a Tiny item on their person with a successful DC 15 Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hand}) check. The chains require a successful DC 20 Strength check to break, or a successful DC 18 Dexterity check using {@item thieves' tools|phb} to unlock. Give characters one night to attempt escape.

Once the stars have aligned (at your discretion), the characters are dragged from the temple to the shallows. They are forced to kneel while the Elders mutter foul utterances. After the ritual finishes, the kraken priests kill the characters by slitting their throats. Characters should have several opportunities to escape during the ritual.

entries.name: Cult of the Kraken
entries: If encountered together, the Elders can each cast the following spells from the warlock's spell list but must share the spell slots among themselves:
Cantrips (at will): {@spell prestidigitation}, {@spell thunderclap|XGE}

1st–5th level (3 5th-level slots): {@spell arms of hadar}, {@spell banishment}, {@spell counterspell}, {@spell crown of madness}, {@spell darkness}, {@spell fear}, {@spell hunger of hadar}, {@spell witch bolt}
For casting these spells, each {@creature kraken priest|VGM} is a 12th-level spellcaster that uses Wisdom as its spellcasting ability (spell save DC 14, {@hit +6} to hit with spell attacks).

entries.name: Northern Trisk
entries: On the northern shore of Trisk is a tower where the Elders commune with Slarkrethel. In the catacombs beneath the tower is a tunnel which leads directly to Ascarle. From this yawning descent lurch debased miscreations whose ilk is not known in the Material Plane. These aberrations from the void between the stars are formed of the malignancy of Slarkrethel manifest, and guard his sacred places.
When characters arrive, read or paraphrase the following:

The lower levels of a crumbling tower jut up from the earth like a broken finger-bone. The exterior of the structure has been lashed by the wind and rain, causing extensive damage. There's something unsettling about the squat ruin. Something ancient.
{@note An unlabelled version of this map can be found {@link here|https://raw.githubusercontent.com/TheGiddyLimit/homebrew/master/_img/CallfromtheDeep/map/The Tower (Player).png}.}

entries.name: Tendrils of Hadar
entries: The dungeon contains a machine which can be used to replicate constellations, found in {@area p6|p6}. The machine is currently set to Tendrils of Hadar, giving all creatures in {@area areas p4|p4|x}—{@area 9|p9|x} disadvantage on Wisdom and Charisma saving throws. See {@area p4|p4} for more information.
A crucified figure hangs from the crumbling tower wall. The corpse is near indescribable; a detestable amalgam of cephalopod and man, decomposition rendering its finer features unrecognisable.

entries.name: Corpse
entries: Characters who see the corpse must succeed on a DC 15 Wisdom saving throw or gain a random form of short-term madness, determined by rolling on the {@table Short-Term Madness} table in {@variantrule madness|dmg|chapter 8} of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}.

Characters who succeed on a DC 20 Intelligence ({@skill Nature}) check can determine that the creature is an aberration from the fathoms below. A successful DC 20 Wisdom ({@skill Medicine}) check reveals the creature died several tendays ago and has been hung here since.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: There are a handful of corals exquisitely carved to resemble starfish beneath the corpse (300 gp).

From this elevation the length and breadth of the northern shore of Trisk is visible. Black waves grasp at the shore as if trying to drag the land down into the depths. The unceasing sound of the tide echoes around in your mind.

entries.name: Pillars
entries: Characters who succeed on a DC 16 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check while atop the tower notice a pair of pillars, one slightly shorter than the other, to the west. These pillars match those on the {@adventure parchment|CallfromtheDeep|15|Sketch of Ascarle's Entrance} in the {@area Abandoned Temple|abandoned temple|x} in Vilsktead. Characters who explore the waters beyond find the location of Ascarle.
The basement level of the tower is dark. The cramped space is entirely empty, save for detritus blown in by the wind.

entries.name: Secret Door
entries: Characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 16 or higher feel a breeze coming from the northeast corner. Characters who succeed on a DC 16 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check discover a secret door, which can be opened by pressing a stone in the wall.

The long, shadowed cavern ahead you reeks of sulphur. The walls are covered with green, viscous ooze. The atmosphere is charged with some malignant force beyond the edge of mortal perception. From this end of the cave, a raised plinth surmounted by an altar of green stone is discernable.

entries.name: Ledge
entries: In the southwest of the cavern is a 20-foot high rock shelf that leads to {@area p7|p7}. Characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 20 or higher hear whispering sounds from the tunnel (see {@area p7|p7}).

entries.name: Statues
entries: Each statue is covered by a thick layer of the harmless green ooze. Clearing away the slime reveals horrific mutations of the human form rendered in jet-black stone: the figures have dozens of thin, drooping tentacles where their faces should be. The base of the statues reads, 'Yogg-Fh'leydn—The Sufferers'.

The statues are psychically linked to the ochre jellies in the room. Any damage dealt to the oozes is instead split between the three statues. When the statues take damage, they cry like a struck animal. The statues have AC 17; 25 hit points; immunity to cold, fire, poison, and psychic damage; and resistance to nonmagical bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage. The connection is broken if a statue is destroyed, or if targeted with {@spell dispel magic} (DC 15).

If a statue is destroyed it emits a hideous scream. Each creature within 30 feet of the statue that can hear it must succeed on a DC 10 Wisdom saving throw or gain a random form of short-term madness, determined by rolling on the {@table Short-Term Madness} table in {@variantrule madness|dmg|chapter 8} of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: There are five starfish-shaped {@creature ochre jelly|MM|ochre jellies} in the chamber, one in each of the five alcoves. The jellies are psychically linked to the statues (see above). They attack any creature that enters the chamber proper.

entries.name: Altar
entries: At the eastern end of the cavern is a 5-foot tall plinth atop which is an altar of green stone. On the altar is a {@item +2 dagger} of coral, a {@item ring of free action}, and two copper chalices with silver filigree depicting tentacled humanoids (25 gp each). The altar is glowing faint purple (see {@area p6|p6}).

On either side of the altar are two tapestries degraded by mould and smeared with green ooze. Drawing the southern tapestry aside reveals a descending tunnel. Characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 20 or higher hear whispering sounds from behind it (see {@area p7|p7}).
Little of worth remains in this storeroom. The dozen or so wooden crates here are covered with a brown, fungous sheet.

entries.name: Brown Mould
entries: {@hazard brown mold|DMG|Brown mould} grows over each crate (see chapter 5 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}).

entries.name: Crates
entries: Characters who succeed on a DC 15 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) or Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check notice that four crates are intact. The crates are nailed shut but can be opened with a successful DC 12 Strength check. The crates contain the following:

items.name: Crate One.
items.entry: Six robes embroidered with a seaweed and tentacle design around the arms (5 gp each).

items.name: Crate Two.
items.entry: Fourteen boxes containing ten purple candles each (1 cp per candle).

items.name: Crate Three.
items.entry: A set of {@item navigator's tools|phb} (25 gp), a brass spyglass covered in verdigris that is always cold to the touch (1,000 gp), three books of astrology and astronomy (25 gp each), and hundreds of pieces of parchment detailing constellations and complex star maps.

items.name: Crate Four.
items.entry: A bronze gong (15 gp) three feet in diameter, a matching hammer, and a wooden box with a bronze kraken clasp. Inside the box is a {@item cursed ring of shooting stars|CallfromtheDeep|ring of shooting stars}. The ring is cursed; any creature attuned to it gains vulnerability to psychic damage.

entries.name: P6. Strong Room
entries: Both stone doors to this chamber are locked. The keys are kept by Ursel in {@area p7|p7}. The doors can be unlocked with a successful DC 18 Dexterity check using {@item thieves' tools|phb}, or smashed down with a successful DC 16 Strength check.
Lorsque les personnages entrent, lisez ou paraphrasez ce qui suit :

Inside this cramped chamber are three wheel-like contraptions made of tarnished metal. The angular devices consist of balls of copper connected by thin rods of steel. Attached to each is a crank and chain. The chamber walls display myriad constellations rendered in shells and corals.

entries.name: Contraptions
entries: Each of the three wheels can be rotated using the crank. The position of the balls can be made to match three different constellation patterns, or scrambled to match none. Characters astrological knowledge, or who have discovered the star maps in {@area p5|p5}, can attempt an Intelligence check to interpret the machinery. The result of the check influences the information revealed:

items.name: 0–10.
items.entry: The character understands nothing.

items.name: 11–15.
items.entry: The character understands the machinery can be rotated to resemble constellations, but doesn't recognise any of them.

The character knows the machinery is currently depicting a constellation called Tendrils of Hadar. The wheels can be rotated to form the Arrows of the Gods, and the Crown. Tendrils of Hadar is an evil constellation, involving the Far Realm-infested star Hadar itself. The Arrows of the Gods indicate true east in the North, and are associated with raiding and war. The Crown is said to be a good omen; a promise of riches to come.

entries: The characters can use the cranks to change the constellation, doing so has the following effects:

items.name: No Constellation.
items.entry: The {@creature shoggoth|CallfromtheDeep} in {@area p9|p9} loses its damage resistances. The altar in {@area p4|p4} stops glowing.

items.name: Tendrils of Hadar.
items.entry: Creatures in the dungeon have disadvantage on Wisdom and Charisma saving throws. The altar in {@area p4|p4} glows purple.

items.name: The Arrows of the Gods.
items.entry: Creatures in the dungeon have advantage on attack rolls and Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) checks. The altar in {@area p4|p4} glows red.

items.name: Crown.
items.entry: Anything that touches the altar in {@area p4|p4} turns to solid gold. If a nonmagical object touches the altar it turns to gold and loses all functionality. If a creature touches the altar it must succeed on a DC 20 Constitution saving throw against being magically {@condition petrified}. On a failed save, the creature begins to turn to gold and is {@condition restrained}. It must repeat the saving throw at the end of its next turn. On a success, the effect ends. On a failure, the creature is {@condition petrified} and is transformed into solid gold. The altar in {@area p4|p4} glows yellow.

entries: Whispered conversation fills this tunnel. A mildew-covered canvas has been nailed into the natural stone wall around half way. The source of the whispering is clearly behind it.

entries.name: Ursel
entries: Whispering to herself behind the canvas is Ursel (CN female Illuskan human {@creature gladiator}). Ursel has been driven insane by the {@creature shoggoth|CallfromtheDeep} which guards the passage between {@area p9|p9} and Ascarle. She was supposed to guard the entrance to the sunken city, but the endless droning of the shoggoth was too much for her to bear. After her mind snapped, she {@condition deafened} herself with a {@item dagger|phb}. Her madness manifests as a near-constant conversation between herself and some invisible being, and a hatred of the colour green.

Before characters can attempt to communicate with Ursel, they must suppress or cure her madness with a {@spell calm emotions} or {@spell greater restoration} spell. Only once her madness is removed can characters converse with her using telepathy, writing, or by succeeding on a DC 15 Intelligence check. Ursel knows the layout of the dungeon, as well as its link to Ascarle. She warns characters to avoid the passage out of fear rather than any lingering devotion to Slarkrethel and the Elders. Ursel knows what {@area p6|p6} contains and has the keys to the chamber, but doesn't understand the workings of the machinery within.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: As well as the keys to {@area p6|p6} and her equipment, Ursel wears a gold ring that resembles a squid (200 gp) and carries a {@item potion of greater healing}. She gives this to the characters if they take the tunnel to Ascarle.

entries.name: P8. Guard Room

entries: This small, unlocked chamber clearly served as a guard room at some point. It contains a narrow wooden bed, a squat table and chairs, and a wide cupboard.
There is nothing of note in this room.

A green stone statue looms high in a chamber opposite a narrow tunnel which descends into the bowels of the earth. The dreadful aspect of the monolith is hard to bear but seems to depict a grotesquely emaciated humanoid carrying a gong in its mouth. The unseeing eyes stare endlessly into the void, or perhaps into the tunnel opposite.

entries.name: Statue
entries: A plaque on the statue reads 'Cthug-Harog—The Warden'. Characters who succeed on a DC 15 Intelligence check realise that using loud noises will subdue whatever lairs in the tunnel.

entries.name: Tunnel
entries: The narrow tunnel descends through the earth for a mile before reaching {@area 32|32} in Ascarle. The tunnel is guarded by a hideous {@creature shoggoth|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) that resides 60 feet into the tunnel, whose aim is to slaughter any who would dare travel to Ascarle. Remember that if the machinery in {@area p6|p6} is set to no constellation, the shoggoth loses its damage resistances.

If characters retrieved the gong from {@area p5|p5}, they can use it to subdue the shoggoth. If a character uses its action to play the gong, the shoggoth can't attack on its next turn. If it is attacked by a character in the meantime, it can use its reaction to take the Actions it would have done on its turn.

entries.name: Character Advancement
entries: After the characters have discovered the entrance to Ascarle, they should reach at least 10th level.

entries.name: Chapter 5: Ascarle
entries: The information the characters have gathered over the course of this adventure should lead them to the sunken city of Ascarle, not far from Purple Rocks. It is here that the powerful kraken Slarkrethel makes its home, and oversees the actions of the Kraken Society. Unknown to most, the kraken has been corrupted by the presence of Zellix'Phor, an elder brain from the Astral Plane whose nautiloid crash-landed on the island of Gundarlun at the start of this adventure. The mind flayer attendants of Zellix'Phor have altered Ascarle to their own needs, and to ensure that Zellix'Phor is protected.

Provided they keep their wits about them, the characters have the chance to destroy the elder brain, its mind flayer attendants, and perhaps even Slarkrethel the kraken. In order to be in with a chance, the characters must solve the puzzle of the abjuration brains (see {@adventure later in this chapter|CallfromtheDeep|9|Abjuration Brains}).

entries.name: Kraken & Elder Brain
entries: Slarkrethel's personality and psyche has been subdued by Zellix'Phor the {@creature elder brain|vgm}. Zellix'Phor has been grafted into Slarkrethel's skull, and uses their psionic abilities to manipulate the kraken to their will. {@creature Slarkrethel|SKT} is a {@creature kraken} with the {@footnote following changes|Included in the linked statblock.}:

items: Slarkrethel has a challenge rating of 25 (75,000 XP).
It casts {@spell foresight} on itself before it attacks.

entries: It gains the Legendary Resistance and Spellcasting features described below.

entries.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If Slarkrethel fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

entries.name: Spellcasting
entries: Slarkrethel is a 20th-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save DC 22; {@hit 14} to hit with spell attacks). It has the following wizard spells prepared:

items: 1st level (4 slots): {@spell comprehend languages}, {@spell detect magic}, {@spell identify}, {@spell sleep}
2nd level (3 slots): {@spell blindness/deafness}, {@spell detect thoughts}, {@spell suggestion}
3rd level (3 slots): {@spell fly}, {@spell nondetection}, {@spell sending}
4th level (3 slots): {@spell arcane eye}, {@spell ice storm}, {@spell locate creature}
5th level (3 slots): {@spell cloudkill}, {@spell scrying}, {@spell telekinesis}
6th level (2 slots): {@spell chain lightning}, {@spell flesh to stone}, {@spell mass suggestion}
7th level (2 slots): {@spell delayed blast fireball}, {@spell sequester}, {@spell teleport}
8th level (1 slot): {@spell control weather}, {@spell feeblemind}
9th level (1 slot): {@spell foresight}, {@spell power word kill}

entries: Zellix'Phor is in full control of Slarkrethel and can use the kraken's actions in place of its own. It can uses the kraken's speed and features, including spellcasting. Although the elder brain maintains its own features and actions, it cannot use its Tentacles while grafted into Slarkrethel.

Characters can choose to attack either the elder brain or the kraken, but the elder brain is protected (see "{@adventure Abjuration Brains|CallfromtheDeep|9|Abjuration Brains}"). This protection is obvious to the characters, who see magical auras surrounding Zellix'Phor.

Zellix'Phor wants to prevent intruders from entering its lair and, of course, wants to avoid dying. There are several 15-foot radius holes throughout Ascarle which lead into the dungeons, allowing the kraken and elder brain to manoeuvre in the dungeon and attack characters.

items.name: If Slarkrethel is about to be killed:
items.entry: Zellix'Phor uses {@spell teleport} to transport itself to {@area 70|70}, where its protective dome should keep it from harm.

items.name: If Zellix'Phor is about to be killed:
items.entry: it casts {@spell plane shift} to travel to the Fractured Hand on the Astral Plane (see "{@adventure Astral Retreat|CallfromtheDeep|9|Astral Retreat}"). The same is true for the various mind flayers that occupy the Dungeons.

entries.name: Ruins of Ascarle
entries: Eons ago, the city of Ascarle was built by moon elves on the northern coast of what came to be known as Trisk of Purple Rocks. They built the city from coral and crystal as they venerated {@deity Deep Sashelas|Elven|mtf} above all other deities. For centuries the elves lived in peace, cultivating unique architecture and art using the materials the ocean provided.

Unfortunately, peace could not last forever. Word of the rich city spread to the drow inhabiting the Underdark, who saw the chance to strike at an unsuspecting elven city and claim its treasures. Motivated by the bitter hatred of {@deity Lolth|Drow|mtf}, the drow sacked the city, killing many elves and routing the rest. The drow desecrated many of the shrines dedicated to {@deity Deep Sashelas|Elven|mtf}, but were kept from entering his most holy temple in the subterranean layer of the city by flooding the chambers with seawater. After spending less than a decade in their captured city, the drow returned to the Underdark.

Over the next century, the ruins of Ascarle were claimed by the Northern ice, which fractured the earth beneath the city, dragging it into the ocean as the glacier melted. Not long after, Slarkrethel discovered this new addition to his underwater realm and claimed it as his own. Since then, Slarkrethel has laired in Ascarle, appointing various evil wardens as Regent to guard the city. The most recent Regent was a rogue illithid named Vestress, who came to power in the 13th century DR.

In the Year of Maidens 1361 DR, the city was assaulted by the drow Lireal Baenre who fatally wounded Vestress and freed the captives from the city. Vestress was interred by the new Regent of Ascarle, an elven queen turned deathlock by Slarkrethel named Shava the Damned.

Within the past year, a major power shift has occurred. Slarkrethel has been dominated by Zellix'Phor, who was grafted into the kraken's skull. Zellix'Phor's illithid colony has taken up host in Ascarle, gaining command over the kraken's followers.

entries.name: Ruin Areas
entries: The ruins of Ascarle spread for miles and have a distinctly elven feel. Little is left of the ancient city, but a few pieces of architecture have defied the ravages of time and tide. Much of the ground is covered by vast forests of seaweed, huge boulders, and ruined walls. The central city is where the Krakenar and Slarkrethel spend most of their time.

entries.name: A. Hidden Entrance
entries: This building is covered with seaweed and is unguarded. Characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 18 or higher notice the building beneath. Entering the ruined chamber requires a successful DC 20 Dexterity check to slip through the destroyed door, or through a crack in the wall. The stairs lead to {@area 1|1} of the Dungeons of Ascarle.

entries.name: B. Northern Entrance
entries: Slarkrethel and Zellix'Phor are here when characters first arrive. The hole in the ocean floor leads to {@area 21|21}.

entries.name: C. Krakenar Entrance
entries: Agents of the Krakenar are permitted to use this entrance to the lair. It is guarded by a triton {@creature champion|vgm} thrall, two {@creature merrow}, and four {@creature sahuagin raider|CallfromtheDeep|sahuagin raiders} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}). The stairs lead to {@area 15|15} of the Dungeons of Ascarle.

entries.name: Baldur's Gate
entries: If the characters failed to rescue Ramazith Flamesinger in Baldur's Gate, there are an additional four {@creature merrow} guarding this entrance.

entries.name: D. Cave-In Entrance
entries: This entrance is inside a crumbling stone building that is covered with boulders. Entering the ruined chamber requires a successful DC 20 Strength check to remove the cave-in or break down a section of wall. The stairs lead to {@area 30|30} of the Dungeons of Ascarle.

entries.name: E. Western Entrance
entries: This entrance is guarded by six {@creature merrow}. It leads to {@area 32|32} of the Dungeons of Ascarle, down a 20-foot drop.

entries.name: Baldur's Gate
entries: If the characters failed to rescue Ramazith Flamesinger in Baldur's Gate, there are an additional four {@creature merrow} guarding this entrance.

entries.name: F. Seaweed Entrance
entries: Characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 16 or higher notice an entrance in the midst of the kelp forest. If their score is 20 or higher, the character notices two {@creature sea lion|tftyp|sea lions} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) guarding the entrance. The sea lions attack any non-Krakenar. The hole leads to {@area 40|40} of the Dungeons of Ascarle, down a 30-foot drop.

entries.name: G. Southern Entrance
entries: This entrance is guarded by two merfolk {@creature kraken priest|vgm|kraken priests} and a {@creature sahuagin baron}. It leads behind {@area 42|42} to the Dungeons of Ascarle, down a 40-foot drop.

entries.name: Baldur's Gate
